chunk norris

crypto (easy)

Chunk Norris is black belt in fast random number generation.

#!/usr/bin/python3 -u

import random
from Crypto.Util.number import *
import gmpy2

a = 0xe64a5f84e2762be5
chunk_size = 64

def gen_prime(bits):
  s = random.getrandbits(chunk_size)

  while True:
    s |= 0xc000000000000001
    p = 0
    for _ in range(bits // chunk_size):
      p = (p << chunk_size) + s
      s = a * s % 2**chunk_size
    if gmpy2.is_prime(p):
      return p

n = gen_prime(1024) * gen_prime(1024)
e = 65537
flag = open("flag.txt", "rb").read()
print('n =', hex(n))
print('e =', hex(e))
print('c =', hex(pow(bytes_to_long(flag), e, n)))

Solution

We can write

p=264⋅15s0+264⋅14s1+⋯+264s14+s15p = 2^{64 \cdot 15} s_0 + 2^{64 \cdot 14} s_1 + \cdots + 2^{64} s_{14} + s_{15}p=264⋅15s0​+264⋅14s1​+⋯+264s14​+s15​

and

q=264⋅15t0+264⋅14t1+⋯+264t14+t15q = 2^{64 \cdot 15} t_0 + 2^{64 \cdot 14} t_1 + \cdots + 2^{64} t_{14} + t_{15}q=264⋅15t0​+264⋅14t1​+⋯+264t14​+t15​

where the sis_isi​ and tit_iti​ are related by

si≡asi−1(mod264)ti≡ati−1(mod264)s_i \equiv as_{i-1} \pmod {2^{64}} \qquad t_i \equiv at_{i-1} \pmod {2^{64}}si​≡asi−1​(mod264)ti​≡ati−1​(mod264)

So

n=22⋅64⋅15s0t0+⋯+264(s14t15+t14s15)+s15t15n = 2^{2 \cdot 64 \cdot 15} s_0 t_0 + \cdots + 2^{64} (s_{14}t_{15} + t_{14}s_{15}) + s_{15} t_{15}n=22⋅64⋅15s0​t0​+⋯+264(s14​t15​+t14​s15​)+s15​t15​

The goal is to recover any of the sis_isi​ or tit_iti​ as each chunk is generated from an LCG so any output will be easily recovered given at least one output.

For simplicity, we'll write s=s15s = s_{15}s=s15​ and t=t15t = t_{15}t=t15​. Then, s14=a−1ss_{14} = a^{-1} ss14​=a−1s and t14=a−1tt_{14} = a^{-1} tt14​=a−1t. Therefore, reducing nnn modulo 21282^{128}2128 we get

n≡264(2a−1st)+st(mod2128)≡st(265a−1+1)(mod2128)\begin{aligned} n &\equiv 2^{64} (2a^{-1}st) + st \pmod {2^{128}} \\ &\equiv st(2^{65}a^{-1} + 1) \pmod {2^{128}} \end{aligned}n​≡264(2a−1st)+st(mod2128)≡st(265a−1+1)(mod2128)​

And since (265a−1+1)(2^{65}a^{-1} + 1)(265a−1+1) is odd, it has a multiplicative inverse modulo 21282^{128}2128.

st≡n(265a−1+1)−1(mod2128)st \equiv n(2^{65}a^{-1} + 1)^{-1} \pmod{ 2^{128} }st≡n(265a−1+1)−1(mod2128)

We can compute the right hand side, and factoring it gives us possible factors for sss and ttt. Since sss and ttt aren't prime, we'll have to play around a bit manually to see which factors are for sss and which are for ttt. This is quite easy to do; we just try to make sss and ttt have roughly the same bit length.

After recovering sss and ttt, we can easily recover all of ppp and qqq by reversing the LCG and decrypt the textbook RSA.

Solve script:

from Crypto.Util.number import long_to_bytes

a = 0xe64a5f84e2762be5
ainv = inverse_mod(a, 2^64)
n = 
e = 0x10001
c = 

st = n * inverse_mod(2^65 * inverse_mod(a, 2^64) + 1, 2^128) % 2^128
print(factor(st))

s = 13 * 167541865434116759
t = 11 * 109 * 223 * 1290533 * 4608287

def gen_backward_prime(s):
    p = s
    for i in range(1,16):
        s = ainv * s % 2^64
        p += s * 2^(64*i)
    return p

p, q = gen_backward_prime(s), gen_backward_prime(t)
d = inverse_mod(e, (p-1)*(q-1))
flag = pow(c,d,n)
print(long_to_bytes(flag).decode())

Flag: CTF{__donald_knuths_lcg_would_be_better_well_i_dont_think_s0__}
